dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains Python concepts, such as data types, control flow, OOP, and libraries.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; demonstrates with live code snippets; explains abstract ideas with concrete Python examples.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague or ambiguous explanations; jumps between syntax and theory without clear linkage; uses jargon without clarification.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, energy, and ability to convey Python syntax and error messages effectively.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear articulation of code; varied tone to emphasize key points; steady pace allowing learners to follow code execution.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone voice; speaks too fast causing missed parentheses; excessive filler words obscuring code explanation.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical organization of Python lessons: introduction, concept explanation, coding demonstration, hands‑on exercise, summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with problem statement, walks through solution step‑by‑step, highlights key Python constructs, ends with recap and next steps.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Randomly shows code snippets without context; skips prerequisite concepts; no clear transition between topics.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners, prompting them to write code, ask questions, and debug together.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses coding challenges, asks learners to predict output, encourages pair‑programming, checks understanding through quick quizzes.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: One‑way lecture; never invites questions; no opportunities for learners to practice writing Python code.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of Python syntax, semantics, and best practices presented.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Demonstrates correct syntax; explains nuances of Python version differences; follows PEP 8 conventions.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Shows code with syntax errors; misstates behavior of built‑in functions; recommends outdated or insecure practices.
